``` ::: ::: # Exploratory Plots We `groupby` `species` and `sex`, `select`ing the length of number of rows. Then, we simply find the `unique` rows. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.julia .cell-code} g_data = @pipe data |> groupby(_, [:species, :sex]) |> combine(_, :sex=>length=>:counts) |> unique labels = map(zip(g_data[!, :species], g_data[!, :sex])) do (i,j) "$(i)-$(j)" end plot(labels, g_data[!, :counts], st=:bar, title="Counts", label=false) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-5-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.julia .cell-code} @. linear_model(x, p) = p[1]*x + p[2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` linear_model (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function plot_corrs(data, variable) p = plot(title=variable) ds1 = @pipe data |> _[!, [:species, variable, :body_mass_g]] |> groupby(_, :species) for sdf in ds1 color = palette(:auto)[length(p.series_list)÷2 + 1] scatter!(sdf[!, variable], sdf[!, :body_mass_g], label=sdf[!, :species][1], markersize=2, color=color ) fit = curve_fit( linear_model, sdf[!, variable], sdf[!, :body_mass_g], [0., 0.], ) plot!( sdf[!, variable], linear_model(sdf[!, variable], fit.param), label=sdf[!, :species][1], lw = 2, color=color ) end return p end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` plot_corrs (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.julia .cell-code} plot( plot_corrs(data, :bill_depth_mm), plot_corrs(data, :bill_length_mm), plot_corrs(data, :flipper_length_mm), layout=(1,3), size=(1300, 400), ylabel="body_mass_g" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-8-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: # First Model ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.julia .cell-code} fit_model_1 = lm( @formula(body_mass_g ~ bill_depth_mm + bill_length_mm + flipper_length_mm + sex), data, ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` StatsModels.TableRegressionModel{LinearModel{GLM.LmResp{Vector{Float64}}, GLM.DensePredChol{Float64, LinearAlgebra.CholeskyPivoted{Float64, Matrix{Float64}, Vector{Int64}}}}, Matrix{Float64}} body_mass_g ~ 1 + bill_depth_mm + bill_length_mm + flipper_length_mm + sex Coefficients: ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Coef. Std. Error t Pr(>|t|) Lower 95% Upper 95% ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── (Intercept) -2288.46 631.58 -3.62 0.0003 -3530.92 -1046.01 bill_depth_mm -86.0882 15.5698 -5.53 <1e-07 -116.718 -55.4589 bill_length_mm -2.32868 4.6843 -0.50 0.6194 -11.5437 6.88638 flipper_length_mm 38.8258 2.44776 15.86 <1e-41 34.0105 43.6411 sex: male 541.029 51.7098 10.46 <1e-21 439.304 642.753 ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── ``` ::: ::: We can do the ftest against the null model as ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.julia .cell-code} ftest(fit_model_1.model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ``` F-test against the null model: F-statistic: 381.30 on 333 observations and 4 degrees of freedom, p-value: <1e-99 ``` ::: ::: ## Diagnostic Plots ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.julia .cell-code} x = predict(fit_model_1) y = residuals(fit_model_1) ystd = (y .- mean(y))/std(y); ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.julia .cell-code} scatter(x, y, title="Residuals vs Prediction", label=false) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-12-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.julia .cell-code} qqplot(Normal(), ystd, title="qqplot of the standardized residuals") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-13-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.julia .cell-code} scatter(x, sqrt.(abs.(ystd)), ylabel="√(Std Residuals)", xlabel="Prediction", label=false) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-14-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.julia .cell-code} cdist = cooksdistance(fit_model_1) plot(cdist, st=:sticks, title="Cook's Distance", label="") high_dist = findall(>(0.02), cdist) hist_dist_annots = map(high_dist) do i (i, cdist[i]+0.002, text(string(i), 8)) end annotate!(hist_dist_annots) hline!([0.02], linestyle=:dash, label=false) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-15-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: ::: callout-caution ## Unimplemented function The leverage function is not implemented in the `GLM.jl` package yet, but there is a [PR in draft](https://github.com/JuliaStats/GLM.jl/pull/510). ::: # Second Model ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.julia .cell-code} fit_model_2 = lm( @formula(body_mass_g ~ species + island + bill_depth_mm + bill_length_mm + flipper_length_mm + sex), data, ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` StatsModels.TableRegressionModel{LinearModel{GLM.LmResp{Vector{Float64}}, GLM.DensePredChol{Float64, LinearAlgebra.CholeskyPivoted{Float64, Matrix{Float64}, Vector{Int64}}}}, Matrix{Float64}} body_mass_g ~ 1 + species + island + bill_depth_mm + bill_length_mm + flipper_length_mm + sex Coefficients: ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Coef. You can partition the data using the following function: ::: {.cell execution_count=17} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using Random function partition_data(data, train_frac = 0.7) n = nrow(data) idx = shuffle(1:n) train_idx = @view idx[1:floor(Int, train_frac*n)] test_idx = @view idx[(floor(Int, train_frac*n)+1):n] data[train_idx, :], data[test_idx, :] end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18} ``` partition_data (generic function with 2 methods) ``` ::: :::
